Award.AwardTitle: CAPP: Combining Algal and Plant Photosynthesis
Award.AbstractNarration:
There is a clear need to increase crop productivity to feed our growing population. The enzyme RuBisCO is critical for the fixation of carbon dioxide into sugars in all plants, but its low efficiency makes it a major bottleneck in photosynthesis. To compensate for RuBisCO's low efficiency, plants with a photosynthetic process known as "C-3" (such as rice and wheat) devote a large fraction of their resources to producing the RuBisCO protein, which constitutes up to 50% of the total protein in their leaves. Unlike C3 plants, many algae have developed a means to drastically reduce the amounts of RuBisCO protein needed for efficient photosynthesis, by using a biophysical carbon concentrating mechanism (CCM). The CCM increases the carbon dioxide concentration within a subcellular compartment called the pyrenoid where RuBisCO is located, thus enhancing carbon dioxide assimilation with less RuBisCO protein.
The ambitious goal of this program is to transfer the CCM from the green alga Chlamydomonas to the model C3 plant Arabidopsis, thus improving rates of carbon dioxide assimilation. The program will use a cutting-edge genome-wide screen to discover novel components of the algal CCM, including pyrenoid components. The physiological functions, localizations and physical interactions of known and newly-discovered components will be characterized by molecular and cell biological approaches, including electron microscopy and mass spectrometry. A modified RuBisCO will be developed and inserted into Arabidopsis to enable formation of a pyrenoid-like organelle. Known components and, progressively, key newly-discovered components, will be transferred to Arabidopsis and their impact on photosynthesis will be assessed. The process will be guided and supported by the development of advanced computational models.
This transformative program represents a leap forward towards improving the photosynthetic efficiency of C3 crop plants, by introduction of a biophysical CCM from green algae. Additionally, the research will provide a much clearer molecular definition of the algal CCM, which is a fundamentally important yet poorly understood biological process. The research will provide undergraduate students opportunities to learn from a broad base of biological research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Combining Algal and Plant Photosynthesis (CAPP) project is an international collaboration that aims to lay the scientific foundations for enhancing the efficiency of photosynthesis in crops. Plants grow by making sugar from carbon dioxide (CO2) in the air. CO2 is present at a very low abundance in our atmosphere, and the growth rate of many crops (including rice, wheat and soybean) is often limited by their ability to take up CO2.

Single-celled green algae have invented a way to take up more CO2 from their environment: a so-called "Carbon Concentrating Mechanism" (CCM). The CCM works by "sucking" CO2 from the environment and concentrating it around Rubisco, the enzyme that makes sugar from CO2.

The CAPP project aims to understand the algal CCM sufficiently to enable its transfer to crops, which could increase crop yields by up to 50% according to some models. To be successful, we need to identify the list of parts required for the mechanism to work, understand how they work, and figure out how to transfer them into higher plants. The challenge is made greater by the limited genetic tools available for characterizing molecular functions in algae.

In the first three years of work funded by this grant, we have developed cutting-edge tools and applied them to identify and characterize new components of the algal CCM; and our UK collaborators have characterized the dynamics of the CCM under dark/light transitions and have initiated the transfer of components to model higher plants. Specifically, we developed a pipeline for high-throughput identification of mutants disrupted in the algal carbon concentrating mechanism. We also developed a novel tool, ChlaMmeSeq, which allows the rapid identification of mutagenic insertion sites in thousands of transformants of the green alga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii. We used our mapping tools to identify dozens of candidate genes with roles in the carbon concentrating mechanism. In the continuation of the grant, CAPP2, we are characterizing new components and working to establish a functional algal carbon concentrating mechanism in a higher plant.

This project has provided an opportunity for scientific training of many participants, including a total of fourteen summer undergraduate internships, two technicians, three graduate students, and four postdoctoral fellows. Several online resources have been developed for providing educational materials to the general public, and outreach presentations and public lectures on the project have been made by the PIs.
